KryRQ7b1gTETnHLzmR4MUA.text: Crispy duck is the bomb! Food coma alert. Good vibes.

xj29-Yn6rr65hasbAnl5zg.text: On a scale 1-10 this gastro pub and especially the food gets 15 points! A Small piece of heaven in earth for a hungry shopper.

-iRlSU9Xd6TCbCmQdBuZsg.text: I highly recommend this restaurant! My husband and I went to this restaurant while on our honeymoon in London and had the BEST meal of the trip. The food is amazing, the ambiance is great, and the service was excellent. We are so happy that a friend suggested this restaurant and will definitely go back on our next trip to London.

bUfO7VjRBfxCz46Ni-Agpw.text: Luckily for me, I didn't realise this was a Hakkasan owned place until later... I'm guessing by some of the grumbles people had come in expecting the same quality. This place isn't anywhere near that level of food...BUT... It's still good!! We went for the crispy duck, some dim sum and a spicy noodles. The dim sum was ok (better than most places but not the best) the noodles were good although spicyer that expected, which was good for me as I like them like that. The duck was really good!!! We went for the half and it was easily enough for 4. We didn't have any issue with the food or the service bit quite a few people round us were grumbling about the seating and food. The price is mid level, not cheap but good for a treat.The bar/restaurant is very cool looking although I don't think it works as a pub... It's a restaurant, a nice restaurant. The beer menu is extensive but mostly bottles, very few on tap (that were on the menu)One down fall is the seating is a little on top of each other, a fact that was obviously getting th complaints. I reckon a few more weeks and this place will have it all worked out and it will be a top place for a night out.

jAsHYAIXV69F6WL51-ApNw.text: Great place, we stopped in twice in one day because we needed to go back and have one of their G&T specials again (the Gin Mare). Atmosphere is chill, and the food at the bar was pretty good. The best of what we tried was the duck spring roll and a spicy pork and prawn noodle dish. The dumplings and pork chips were just ok. Will be going back for the drinks and to try the restaurant for sure!

hFslUPipXQWCn4G-3nDJRw.text: friend ended up with diarrhea!!!nice decor dreadful food ok servicei know i can be very harsh with my reviews but i honestly would feel sad if you went through what I've been so at least let me warn you :)was here on a saturday 10 days agosaturady 8pm we're in soho and we were hungry! ha we didn't have any reservations big mistake on a sat night in londonfriend wanted to eat in some place in soho i know my stuff and i wanted to eat in yahuatchaso we ended up in yahuatcha' just to learnt that it was full ha so we went next door Duck and Rice which looks very nice from outside but ..the ground floor looks like a pub and the restaurant is upstairs nice decor walls, tables, the tables are lined up in an awkward way..they told us that they might have a table so we waited, i wanted to leave i knew food wasn't gonna be good (call it six sense haha i just know) but friend wanted to stay :(so as i said dreadful food,dish called shredded meat DISGUSTING! couldn't eat it, i have no problem in sending back something thats awful but friend didn't want to moaning and all he eat it! felt sorry for him! haha but was funny watching him eating it and pulling faces ha ha!! when the waiter came back for feedback my friend said food is ok (typical british) i said food is pretty average awful' sorry couldn't eat it' to what the waiter answered, its ok i understand! haha what does that mean? dear waiter You are meant to say i apologise would you like anything else instead????? or don't worry its on the house! as i wasn't paying i didn't mind as friend said its ok leave it!squid was awful anyway Mediocre dreadful food!!!!!!around 1am when i got home was feeling a bit funny it was 3am and couldnt sleep because i had stomach ache headache, next morning my friend texted me saying he had bad diarrhoea that night! he blamed the squid!there you go!ill never go back again!Surprised tbh as its the same chef Alan Yau from yahuatcha!

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. We ended up in Duck&rice as Yauatcha was full. Good decor Dreadful food. Pricey' Food is a let down! You been warned'
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

737grQa0DVG1LtOIZbfipQ.text: It was a day of relatively disappointing expensive food. London can be so hit and miss sometimes. Having used to live in the neighborhood, I've been wanting to try the Duck and Rice ever since it was supposed to open in 2014. It finally did in 2015 and it truly became for the East Asian foodie community in London, one of the most anticipated restaurant openings. I've tried on numerous occasions, as I would never sit down at the bar, to book a table and have dinner here, but 1. the prices scared me away, and 2. it was impossible to get a table. I've walked in here probably as many times as I've called and without success either. So, of course,, I pick the last Saturday to walk in with friends and we do get seated, only because someone else didn't show. Anyway, as luck would have it, I should have probably listened to the unluckiness from before and stopped trying to come here. The food is definitely decent, and flavorful, but good lord is it salty. We had the salt and pepper squid, the kai lan seasonal veggies, the malaysian duck curry, the ribs and the black pepper glass noodles. Everything but the duck curry was overly seasoned and doused in garlic - I wondered if there was a whole bunch that they needed to use and just made things extra garlicky. Anyway, what you're really paying for is the renovation of this once a watering hole for the locals of Soho - much to my utmost annoyance. The atmosphere fits one of my core values - i.e. it's young and it's introducing Chinese food to British yuppies (albeit in a laid back, rather contrived pub/club vibe, reeking of TOWIEsque lads and lasses). It also completely violates another of my core values that food should come first and the environment compliment rather than cover for the lack of good cooking. Service is good, however, and redeems this place from a bottom of the heap finish. However, for £30 a head, I'd rather have stuffed myself silly at equally qualified, probably even finer cuisine at Royal China or Phoenix Palace.

1rpQvn-vwNng0ZErO4WClg.text: Coming from NYC we did not know what to expect. We loved the place. It started with a great seat overlooking Berwick, followed by Jacques who was the best waiter we encountered in London and then with his assistance we sampled a great portion of the menu including sesame prawn toast, pork bun, Szechuan chicken dumplings, signature duck, egg fried rice and #23. We concluded with chocolate pudding with lemon creme anglaise. When we return to London we will be back

9R1ui9v0fObbYVVq1CDb6A.text: 1. The restaurant: Great Interior, and ambiance. It's very relaxing. I could see myself staying hours. 2. The drinks: looked great but didn't have any. 3. Food:- hot and sour soup: smelled like sewage, and fertilizer. My girlfriend said the soup reminded her of her unwashed dogs. - duck salad: was good but not as great as in Hakkasan- sweet and sour pork: very good!!- wasabi prawns: they were fried and tasted fine. The best wasabi prawns in London are however at Kai Mayfair. - prawns and vermicelli noodles with cucumber: tasted extremely fishy. They tasted like when you walk into a fish market. And they were made with dried shrimp. I didn't like them. Altogether positive because we received 50% off the bill (which is valid for new guests for another 2 days according to the restaurant). We paid £40, for which the value was good! However if I would've paid £80 (without drinks) I would have not come back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

OGiQghuW3ISOwSBsH2aPKA.text: I ordered sweet and sour pork with rice and it was delicious! Importantly, it was NOT overly battered like you usually get with those take-away places. My meal actually tasted like pork and not some derivative version of pork. Good size portion and paid 8.50 for it.

1gC2bDhQ0p9veQkOGjeyUA.text: Great for the ambience. Has a nice buzz. Feels like a good place to go out for a meal out. Food is just ok. On par with a good Chinese restaurant but much better is easily found. If you aren't too fussy about your Chinese food or don't eat it too often, you will probably enjoy this. If you go in expecting hakkassan or yauatcha quality, you will be disappointed.

M04cs6BXAjRiOIuPwCDxBw.text: Dined here on Sunday night for my daughter's 15th birthday. Food was exceptional, service was attentive and staff sang happy birthday to her :-) Thank you everyone at the Duck & Rice for a very memorable time. Also, love quiz night with Cookie MonStar, it was definitely an eye opener for both my daughters (15 yo & 10yo)! The pepper chicken wings were a big hit for us... we ordered two orders of it!

4DV1iV8ie4EMZPvKaUwKPg.text: This place was a lot of fun. I will definitely go back. My only complaint was that I ate to much food! Interesting place architecturally.

q8t8lNy-e6PvYGeDEFh_zg.text: Alan Yau does it again (and much better here than Bababji)! Not sure if the concept is so much gastropub but the food and drinks were very good. We had the crispy duck and the duck and the pancakes were perfect. The special fried rice has egg fried rice on the bottom topped with chicken, prawns and veggies in a brown sauce. Mixed together it was very good. Dim sum was on par with Yauatcha -- very well executed and not greasy. I would skip the ginger chicken - the chicken was dry and the ginger sauce surprisingly was flavourless.

SroW-klZRiQQAD_BFEEAzQ.text: Two words - crispy duck.  Served with "pancakes" (think Asian tortillas), veggies and a sweet brown sauce.  Incredible service and what a scene, bar downstairs was absolutely jumping when we arrived.  Everything was great but sesame prawn toast was the other truly unique item that was spectacular.  Highly recommend it, our waiter Vikish (sp?) crushed it and this is definitely a place to go with the waiter.

SaubDkXxH7xKdqbnSHkFFA.text: The best crispy aromatic duck in London hands down. Starters are the best I've ever had.

ZV7yDqKidAZrxEz0MGyEdg.text: Not the Chinese restaurant that will offer any special Chinese New Year atmosphere. Nonetheless the food turned out better than expected. What was poor is the service and attitude, which is a far cry from deserving the automatic 12.5% service charge. Firstly, all the signature dishes were not available, this deserved a mention when we initially made the reservation. Doubt we will return based on our experience.

T1Cn3hg73YExnANFQUj1NQ.text: Throughout our time in London we never had concrete plans of where we wanted to eat so we picked restaurants that looked good walking around. From the outside, Duck and Rice looked like a very hip restaurant with the open windows on the second floor. It was packed! Knowing how busy it was, we still gave it a shot and asked if they had a table for two. Luckily, we didn't have to wait long and were seated within five minutes.The decor was cool, although they crammed a lot of tables on both floors. We had a table on the second floor that was very difficult to get in and out of. Our waiter was nice, but with a heavy non-British accent he was often hard to understand.We started off with two beers and ordered the crispy duck fried rice and lemon chicken. What I thought was odd was that the lemon chicken didn't come with rice or noodles on the side, you had to pay extra for it. Duck fried rice was good, but really lacking on both the flavor and amount of crispy duck. Lemon chicken had great flavor especially in conjunction with the rice we ordered (egg fried rice).Based on reviews, a lot of people are saying it's fairly expensive, but I'm used to paying a premium for a meal at home so I can't necessarily agree. Although, I don't think the flavor of the food necessarily warrants a second trip if I'm back in London.

_sqAChYCnbodpnSNlHECPw.text: I finally tried the Duck And Rice a Chinese gastropub opened few years ago by the owner of Hakkasan (it has been sold to a different owner these days)  in the heart of Soho. It is an stylish pub with upstairs dining room serving Chinese (fusion) dishes (dim sum, chow mei or noodle dishes, chow sui or stir fries...). We had wasabi prawns, crispy beef and Singapore noodles. It was plenty of food for two. The crispy beef is very particular, really really crispy and a bit sweet it tasted very good but I wouldn't eat a lot of it. The prawns and the Singapore noodles were very good. They had fresh mandarin juice that it was very small but really good. Including service and no alcohol we paid slightly over £50. Very good attentive service.

DC4zkpifsJy_hnbnPVsWrQ.text: I went there for a dinner with my friend. The environment is an interesting western eastern blend. The duck and rice is good and I love the scallop shumai. I'll probably go there again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

VJi9oXsn6Kr1lVWP9qPcmg.text: Overall a very pleasant experience and will be returning in near future. All of the food ordered was tasty. The venue is rather loud so a bit hard to hear but offers a buzzing environment. Slight negative was arriving on time but told to wait at the bar, ie order drinks before dining.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Gin and tonics
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding

AyMIcwGGleaVt6mTSrwsFQ.text: Food was excellent. The duck and dim sum were excellent. I am not including the final star, however, because the duck is almost identical to a place where I live (Lien Hoa in Little Saigon) and it costs about half the price. I think this place is a bit overpriced, but it is good nonetheless.The service was excellent and I had a great time there! The drinks were good and the bartender is heavy handed.

ERLjTgZwRrvlrHNv-RoOag.text: Ordered an array of small plates for a work lunch - we loved every dish! Not even sure which our favourite was. Also- very fast service and very nice staff. Would absolutely recommend!!

2lgkJPLRdABJQpZWmXnaFA.text: The food in particular isn't amazing but I think it's a cool place to get a beer and snacks. Thought the namesake duck and rice, fried chicken, and venison puffs were really good. They also have a good selection of beer and wine.It's best during weekdays, when it's a little quieter and you want to have a chat with your friends.

IIDW6c2PrFo9Mq7WLgHgJg.text: Fabulous Dim Sum, cool vibe with their own Wifi station to memorialize the experience. Great quality at reasonable prices - I vote YES!

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

yRMDj8po9kFDiuRO1jiLVQ.text: Tried (in vain) to get into Hoppers. In the process of being disappointed by their hostess who told everyone outside that no more table requests were being taken for that entire evening at 5:00(!), struck up a conversation with a lovely Brit who was in the same fix -- he recommended we try The Duck and Rice, though he said he thought it might be equally hard to get into. As dinner time approached we found our way to Berwick Street and amazingly grabbed their last table for two! What a great place -- noisy, crazy, fun street level with bar and somewhat quieter but still super bouncy second level up the winding staircase. )Side note: they might have the most comfortable chairs I've ever sat on in a restaurant.)  Tucked into a G & T with a licorice stick and munched on edamame - perfect with flakes of salt. The husband and I started with Sesame Prawn Toast and Jasmine Tea Smoked Rib Bao Buns. Holy smokes they were good -- I could probably live on the Bao Buns for several months and not miss a single other item of food! Main dishes were French Bean Stir Fry and Singapore Fried Noodles -- equally delicious and just enough of an after burn to make us happy - Yay! The service was fantastic -- friendly and helpful and the energy of the place made the whole evening memorable. Thank God we met that lovely man outside of Hoppers!

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

M6-PBYk0IzEVq2Z4xzcb3g.text: Pleasantly surprised by this place, and it has the potential for 5*s!A pub style Chinese sounded to good to be true-It wasn't. This place has a brilliant drink selection-I had a few different beers and then some Gin and Tonics...all really good!The main attraction was the food, I think London struggles with affordable, nice Chinese food, so was over the moon when I found here.We tried quite a bit, with my favourites starting to pile up. some highlights included--Salt and Pepper squid-fresh, tasty and not grease in sight-Duck Rolls-loved these-really tasty and fresh-The BBQ ribs-again really tasty, lots of meat and good flavours-The duck-a must for any Chinese for me, and these guys got it spot on!So the reasons we are a star short-the waiter forgot we ordered shredded beef (one of my favourites), and when we reminded him, we were told the kitchen was shut so we couldn't have it. Not something I expect to hear in a restaurant really...just still the pan on and cook some up. We were a big table spending a lot of money so the response was surprising. Top 3 tips for this place-1.Book, it can get busy, especially if you are a big group. They don't have many larger tables. 2.Share-loads of great things are on the menu so don't all order the same, mix it up and taste everything3.The drinks are great, so try a few and give yourself time to chill in the pub down the stairs to carry on the afternoon/evening

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Duck and Rice-Lobster, Chicken, Ribs and a bit more

ARh7hE2kyttdOfMWHEhW3g.text: Duck and Rice has been one of the most hotly anticipated restaurant openings for this year, coming from London restaurateur Alan Yau, the owner of Yauatcha, Hakkasan and Wagamama. The idea is a Chinese themed gastropub in prime Soho real estate, right around the corner from Yauatcha. I thought it would be incredibly difficult to get a table, so when I emailed the reservations line a week ago, the request was more along the lines of "when is your next available table?" rather than "can I get a table next week?" But to my surprise, I was able to get a table on opening day, April 13, at my requested time of 7 PM without a problem.The entrance is dominated by a large copper beer tank, and behind it are tables that are arranged in a high table quasi-bar setting, and I think you can just walk in there. I was confused because there was no around to check my reservation, so I wandered upstairs, which was a more obviously restaurant setting. The first day was not super crowded, as I could see the odd empty table here and there, but also not very chaotic, which I guess is the benefit of having a few weeks of soft openings already.The menu is large and very overwhelming, with one side dedicated to food and the other, entirely to drinks. However, the menu items have no descriptions, and even with the experience of having eaten a lot of Chinese food over the years, I found myself asking the waiter a lot of questions because I didn't recognise so many of the names. In the end, we ordered two dim sum dishes - a venison puff and duck spring rolls, Singapore fried noodles, Jasmined smoked pork rib, crispy shredded beef, and some steamed rice. The waiter recommended one more dish, but that was already more than enough food. I had really wanted to order some seasonal vegetables, but at around £10 for nothing more interesting than bok choy, it seemed like a total rip off.The first 3 plates were our dim sum dishes and the Singapore fried noodles. I loved both the venison puff and the spring rolls - you get 3 of the former and 2 of the latter, but the spring rolls are huge and cut in half, and are served with a lovely hoisin sauce. They are also very generously stuffed with duck meat, so you can't go wrong here. The Singapore noodles were the size of a main, and the main reason that we thought that we had gotten too much food. They were very heavily spiced and extremely flavorful... but definitely was enough to comfortably share between 4-5 people.Next we had the Jasmine smoked pork rib and the crispy shredded beef. When we ordered, I had asked a lot about the crispy shredded beef, as I had never heard of anything like it before, and our Spanish waiter sounded like he didn't know much more, except that it was a highly recommended dish. It was very disappointing. In theory, they shred some beef and deep fry it, but in the end it came out like crunchy pork rind or something, served with enormous Sichuan peppers and rather unmemorable in terms of taste. The Jasmine smoked pork rib was the exact opposite, with a rack of about 7 ribs and an intensely strong smoky flavour, and very unique.Throughout the whole meal, I had the Czech pilsner and my friend had a Chinese beer and then a Japanese beer, both of which were wheat beers that tasted like Hoegaarden. The one thing I will say is that the foreign bottled beers do not come cheap - they are upwards of £7. The ones on tap are all European, with the likes of London Pride, a Scottish pilsner, and even a cider. When we got the bill, we were pleasantly surprised to find out that we had gotten all the food at 50% off, which had not been advertised. It is unclear if they are still doing their soft opening... I asked the waiter and he said that he thought it would go on until Thursday, but it was happening at the manager's discretion. If I had known, I would have definitely gone for the roast duck or the whole lobster! (they were like £40ish)Overall, this restaurant is certainly not cheap at normal prices, but then again it is Soho. It kind of reminds me of Hutong in the Shard, obviously with the focus on the roast duck and fairly similar prices. I don't get a strong impression that they are like a pub, large copper beer tank aside. I might pop in here for a beer, more because they stock some unique ones like the Chinese and Japanese ones my friend had, rather than for the vibe. The dishes are something in between tapas size and main plates, though personally I feel like they should focus on making them more like tapas. I'm glad I got the opportunity to check it out, but I wouldn't be in a rush to return again.

N8a7bS9VD-Ofd1u1nNVAhg.text: There aren't too many Chinese restaurants in London I like, but this certainly is one of the two. Owned by the people behind Hakasan (I think), this place is renowned for its original duck, but goes above and beyond to offer delights like wasabi prawns and more. I have been here twice and loved my meal both times, if only I could remember what else I ordered. It is always busy, any day of the week, so make a reservation.

bgo0nbm6tQF1Gof2rjqCNg.text: Sunday Brunch menu is pretty good, prawn cheung fun is a must try, also crispy duck roll, shanghai xiaolongbao taste so good, very authentic.

E_D4i5yd5Rp48HfS_NQMNg.text: Meh! Went to the bar downstairs at the Duck and Rice but wasn't really feeling it . Vicky L suggested it's because I am freaked out by the fact it's no longer the Endurance pub - the old boozer that existed on this site before Alan Yau restaurateur funked it up with snazzy windows and fittings.  But I suspect it was just because it's not that special.Perhaps my meh ness could be down to pre Christmas fatigue. It was pretty busy, people were unfriendly here (not the staff, just the people) and we moved spots SIX times in the night before we found a place where three of us could drink happily.The menu was a bit of a mash up. Beer cocktails rule the drinks list - perhaps a nod to its public house former life. Some beers cost £8. What kind of weird parallel universe has Alan Yau created where beer costs as much as cocktail?You can get 'pub food' too. Not cheap but decent value to share, and great that it's gastro-Chinese. However the staff weren't able to adequately explain what is in their food - which in my book reaches new levels of Meh-ness.  Although my friends explicitly asked them, they weren't told that shellfish was in the spring rolls. And we were wrongly delivered the salt and pepper squid instead of the chicken. Therefore I ended up accidentally eating two things I shouldn't be eating. Double meh. My pals were happy at least though as they got the squid for free on top of our chicken.Also the music is loud, but allegedly you can control the playlist and queue up a song if you log into their wifi on and go to their website. We were there for an age and we never heard the gorgeous C-Pop song we lovingly picked. It's all lies I tells ya.Oh and one last meh, the downstairs where the toilets were smelt so bad and unpleasant.. But they do redeem themselves with the loos  because they actually had Thomas Crapper cisterns. However it seriously can't be good, when the bogs are the best thing about the Duck and Rice.  So Generally meh - but this is a review just for the downstairs bar. Perhaps I will give it another chance when it's less busy after Christmas, and i expect the restaurant upstairs will be different altogether.

tsf62K_TMapkmEFa5wVR3w.text: Amazingggggggg place for chill drinks and nibbles. The downstairs pub is super trendy and their food is phenomenal. It's decently priced for a London soho hotspot. Haven't tried the food at the Resturant yet but will definitely give it a go next time I'm in the area

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Chicken satay
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Prawn toast
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. House prawn crackers.  amaaaaazing

2kumUyFSszO5F3qMlBubeQ.text: Booking is essential! I can't stress that enough. You may be lucky enough to just walk in but I'd definitely recommend booking or you are most likely going to be disappointed. We had a table upstairs in the back and I have to say our servers were really attentive and friendly. They were really knowledgable of the menu and helpful when it came to helping us choose the right amount of food for our party. All of the food we tried was delicious but particular stand outs were the calamari, the crispy duck and the fried chicken. The gin and tonics there are also pretty excellent!

Iowjpj9vtpvjISRRWJs53w.text: We decided to try The Duck and Rice based on the recommendation of our AirBNB host.  We walked in at 9 pm without reservations and they offered us a seat in the downstairs bar area.  Before we could order, a table upstairs opened and they offered it to us.  We decided to order the Duck & Rice, char sui bao, and 5 spice fried chicken.  Our server suggested that we also try the crispy duck fried rice, which we did.  The 5 spice fried chicken was incredible, as was the crispy duck fried rice.  When we returned a few nights later, we ordered the same meal.  For food and service, Duck & Rice deserves 5 stars.  The noise level, though...  Intense!  It was so loud that your ears would be ringing by the time you left.  Take your earplugs.  Order the 5 spice fried chicken.

ILYNQY1n-zKDNDeolZdz2w.text: The whole premise of a pub with Chinese food is great. The venue itself is lovely inside and the location excellent. The window spots are superb for people watching the huge variety of souls wandering Berwick Street Market, Sohos finest. Sadly I was a little let down by everything else. My char siu bau were small and mainly onion rather than pork. The wines were overpriced and when I asked for a house red was offered the most expensive one on the list. Was very busy and people passing were clearly intrigued. I wasn't convinced however.

iv-jZHIiUk0Z5-H_nKggkA.text: I was told this place was a bit overpriced for what it is and as a recent HK transplant to the city I had my own reservations abt Chinese food plus beer plus hip culture in Soho. I was wrong about all things but one - the food is a tad on the pricey side but it is very delicious. We got wasabi prawns, the crispy aromatic duck and siu mai. The siu mai I was most impressed with - bursting with meaty flavor it could comfortably go head to head in a competition with any HK treat. The duck made me think of a different version of Peking duck - same fixings different kind of duck. Wasabi prawn is tender and had great sauce and almonds. Also worth a special mention is the beer negroni and the wide selection of draft beer. Cool vibe, great service - if I can find a more affordable less trendy version of this place I think I would have found a personal nirvana in the city. In the meantime Duck and Rice is a solid option when I get my Asian food cravings

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Beer negroni
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Prawn and shrimp siu mai
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Crispy aromatic duck (quarter)

Q44VvVrk8DOvY_yZ28Mk1g.text: It was the kind of mid-day that felt like the world was running at low-volume. The sun had risen at 6am and heated the asphalt to a hazy warmth. Lazy tourists, having reached where they had wanted to come, now milled about the streets without a strong sense of where to go next.I quietly slipped into duck and rice where a muted TV played the world-cup in the background. Portugal v. Morocco. The ball was in Portugal's possession, dribbled and passed downfield.What should we get, I pondered? There was a Chinese person from China. Two from Canada. Another, myself, from the USA. All having coalesced in London, we now found ourselves in this Chinese restaurant, which on the outsides were decorated in a mainly western fashion: red-bricks and tin-barrels. Gin instead of Baijiu was on the alcohol menu.On screen, a Moroccan defender challenged the attack. The Portuguese player expertly evaded the slide.Do we want Dim Sum? Cantonese Duck? Crispy Aromatic Duck? Some committed to foods and then pulled out, others had come before and knew what they already wanted: jasmine ribs, duck fried rice.Now downfield, a shot was deflected by Morocco's goalkeeper, the ball flew back for a corner kick.I wondered briefly what kind of food I really wanted - the choice becoming as much a question of my identity as one of the thousands of lunches I've had before. I mean this was a Chinese establishment, right? So maybe I should go with that? But how Chinese could it be given that it was in the heart of London? I bet it could only survive in its location, outside of Chinatown, because of its decor - making white diners feel safe and comfortable in familiar territory. The ribs, I heard, were meant to taste like a Texas BBQ with a dash of jasmine flavor. Which of those were meant to taste like home for me, I wasn't sure.The anticipation built up in the soccer stadium. Players organized themselves in optimal setting to go towards the goal.After careful deliberation, I ventured into a dish that I had never heard of before: the "sha-cha glass noodle claypot" with my comfort zone of egg fried rice on the side. One to keep me grounded with a common narrative thread to the past, the other gave me the possibility to grow into something new.The corner kick flew. Ronaldo appeared. The ball hurtling deep into the net. Portugal went wild. And for a brief moment, the energy of the crowd's cheer passed out of the TV and into my body. And as fast as it came, faded back into the still-muted screen that cast the same scene to millions of people around the world.

FRhwRKjvg2kqOSRHCphJ9Q.text: Really cool place, bar downstairs with the big tanks of Czech Pilsner were a highlight! Atmosphere was good and the waiting staff were all sound. Food wise I wasn't that impressed and we had some issues. The dim sum starter was good, but the chicken gyazo we ordered was quite bland! For the main my girlfriend ordered the Duck and Rice, which came 10 minutes before my own chicken clay pot, which added onto the fact the rice was cold!Staff were more than happy to replace but I just think it spoiled the dinner a bit and when you're paying £15 a main course it's just not on! Like I say, it's a cool place and I know friends who have had some great food here, so definitely worth a try so I think 3 stars is about right.

KZV_eCbrzL-77YbGPQLBVw.text: Duck and Rice is apparently famous and when I arrived on a weekday around 6pm the place was packed full of 20 and 30-somethings grabbing drinks. Definitely a fun vibe though a bit claustrophobic. Despite this, it was decently easy to grab a seat for one at the bar or at one of the smaller bar tables so long as you're ok getting cozy with your neighbor.The duck and rice was pretty good, very flavorful and lots of umami. Given the hype was expecting crunchier skin, more sauce, fluffier rice. That being said, it was a solid duck over rice, but probably not worth going out of your way for if you're visiting.

5vrQAIQ5vaNwYQ86vKDPwA.text: I knew I wanted to have dim sum as my first meal in London because it was an atypical choice. I chose this dimly lit place because it was close to my hotel and just right down the block from the record store I was perusing. Simply put, service and tankard of their draft Czech Republic beer was great. I was expecting worse with their dim sum but, it was decent. Nothing special or memorable about the char-siu bao, scallop shumai or hargow. I am a tough critic on this since I was raised in the land of renown Chinese food outside of China. Their ginger gailan was very good though.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Charsiu bao and gailan
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Hargow, shumai, beer

pnBZ7w0DjuhU-xWI7drQ4w.text: Main Point: a good example of where u have Chinese food that is very par 2 subpar @ a kind of fancy place, where u could have went 2 Chinatown insteadsure if u want 2 go 4 the mood of possibly romantic @ a nice place.. u got my permission 2 go 4 it, do wat u want; nobody's stopping u or pulling ur collar from behind but..Duck and Ricewe had high expectations.. I mean the name, we finally made it in the 2nd try since it was so busy n overhyped as it turnt outpoints:(1) Service lacked @ 1st b/c they don't even know who was supposed 2 serve us(2) Tank Old Fashioned was ok for 11 British Pounds hell 2 the N O!(3) Fried chicken wings, green peppercorn - actually their best but not by much(4) Five spice fried chicken - should have named it I copy American KFC Popcorn Chicken for copyright infringement(5) Crispy aromatic duck - n this is supposed 2 b 1 of their signature dishes.. I don't think so.. go 2 Chinatown's Hung's way better n cheaper.. duck dry, hoisin sauce was ok(6) Pork & prawn shumai - bland n boring2 stars; I've experienced much better.. believe me, u won't miss a thing

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. our view
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Crispy aromatic duck
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Pork & prawn shumai

rYjWDeZaeDPgN5vsk7meKA.text: More of a 3.5 star. Good place for a dim sum group lunch & share everything! Not expensive, we had 5 people and it cost 20/person. Overall not the best dim sum but above average & you can make reservations online! The interior is quite nice especially the second floor near the window. You get a lot of light.MUST GET: pork & shrimp shumai, baked pork buns (the baked ones are better than the steamed ones here), shrimp changfunDON'T NEED TO GET: shrimp & chive steamed dumplings, har gao (shrimp dumplings)

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. 2nd floor interior
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. front door

qCf480pi8b47BcuImuxWfQ.text: Great place. Food is delicious, mix of mainly Chinese with other Pan-Asian fusion dishes. You'd think a place that has duck in its name has great duck. It does. The crispy duck with pancakes and plum sauce is a must have. The salt and pepper aubergine, currently a special, should be a mainstay. The Baos are also very good. Desert selection is limited but you probably won't have that much space left; the sticky toffee seems boxed but is still tasty.Bar-wise, good selection of tap beer. Interesting beer-based cocktails if you are curious. The gin cocktails are underwhelming. The  decor elegantly walks  the fine line between trendy and pretentious.  Service is very good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Salt and pepper  aubergine. Get this monthly special.

JSEc874FmAZQeiohAorR_A.text: I will recommend this place for a fancy dinner or maybe a date dinner since it's a bite pricy. Also, it's not authentic Chinese food it's more Asian Fusion foodI like the decoration : it's a mix of Asian elements with modern, European style furnishures.The service is good, and our waiter was nice and efficient even if we were a huge table of 14 people.We ordered several dishes to share like the (of course) duck and rice, some greens, lettuce wraps, yakitori, crispy duck rolls,special fried rice, Pak choi,...The food was delicious, really tasty and I was really full at the end.For drinks I had the Imperial Iced tea which wasnt too sweet.A nice place but pricy in Soho. I won't go often but I will go back for sure !

d5cBUHLcYFJ1sD3BTjasYQ.text: Went on a weekday for dinner. We ordered the crispy aromatic duck, wasabi prawns and the special fried rice. Food 4/5, service 3/5.

6Ay_lZBEKrqgvHq9OpGImA.text: We booked ahead as had heard it can be really busy... it was a Tuesday night and we sat down at 9pm and went specially for the Cantonese duck and rice... we ordered two, the waitress looks at me plainly 'there won't be any duck left now' I thought she was joking, Infact I insisted laughing as if it was a funny joke, that we'd love the duck, 'I'll have to check with the kitchen' she said 'it's most likely we won't have any' - long story short we left, considering we booked ahead I felt that we should have asked if we were going to order the duck... they are called duck and rice... it's a stone throw away from China town so we went there for a wonderful and cheaper meal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

dUatssBZ6VlooBrYgJM0Ow.text: The duck and rice is actually good coming from Hong Kong-er who is travelling London and lived in a very multi-cultural city of Toronto, Canada

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

EehHXXXjqmVVMzhfHAfH0Q.text: Ambience: The decor in this restaurant was very nice - themed as a "Chinese pub". Our table was in the second floor with sliding terrace doors overlooking Berwick street (see photos). The staff were very polite and very attentive. Food: We ordered prawn crackers, dim sum, quarter crippling duck, the No. 23 and a side of jasmine rice. The dumplings were ok, could have been a bit more flavoursome (but I'm not a dumpling expert). The quarter crispy duck was delicious, served with pancakes. The No. 23 was quite normal, noodles with chicken; nothing too special. Overall the food was decent.Price: The price was very reasonable given the amount of food there was on the table!

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Receipt
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Opened terrace doors
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Jasmine rice

dTMjpToTFGQxFs1Ma_9u4g.text: The first waitress had her ass in my food while taking other people's orders (photo attached). The second waitress dropped our glass bottle and told us it was almost empty and didn't bring a new one. Duck was over cooked resulting it being  burnt, the cucumbers were to thick, and pancakes cold. I was already pissed and needed to use the restroom which was 6 flights of stairs down with no light, very convenient after a heavy meal. My wife was frustrated and thank god I was able to calm her down with the new yoga breaths I learned last night. You can waste your time and go here or you can go to Mr.Chow or any other authentic Chinese restaurant that serves duck.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. 1st waitress had her ass in my food while taking other people's orders.

_70Wpq31YMUluFQrsO3U1g.text: Owned by Hakassan, so you'll definitely get solid food.  The crispy duck was definitely crispy and wasn't dry and others have pointed out. Presentation and decor make for such fancy Chinese food, but it comes with a ££££ price tag. Ehh, it was good, but I don't think it warrants the cost and a second trip.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom

YacLy8y-uKA7sbF5vOEzKA.text: The couple of things that we got really hit the spot.Starter of the salt and pepper squid - no calamari tentacles, only the cut up and scored strips.  Sessoned well and tarnished with pepper and green onions.  Maybe a it pricey at 10 pounds but claimari at western places is in the same zip code.Got the jasmine smoked pork ribs and a quarter of the house duck.  Both great.  The jasmine smoke ribs aren't going to be western BBQ style - a little dryer.  On the other hand, the house duck is served room temperature in a rich sauce.  Super delicious (probably unhealthy).Topped it off with rice and a glass noodle.The ambience is hip as people say and the seating cramped, service mediocre (took a long time to order and wrap up), but I'd be excited to come back and try some more plates.  Hope we didn't blow it eating all the best stuff!

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. Salt and pepper squid

qpyi2j_AUrohL8G027hgbQ.text: The food was delicious -- for lunch we had har gau, xiaolongbao, fried taro root dumpling, duck fried rice, ramen noodles for my vegetarian husband, and aubergine with mui choi. The dumplings were all perfect; the duck fried rice cooked to perfection with mouth-watering crispy duck. I would have appreciated a higher duck-to-rice ratio, but it was overall a satisfying meal.As much as the food is high quality, this restaurant is extremely pricey. There are few to no Chinese people who eat here (I'm Chinese-American, so I don't know where the local Chinese go to eat high quality dim sum, but it's definitely not here).  There are probably better places to go for great dim sum, but if you have the money and you are not sure what the alternatives are, you can't go wrong here. The restaurant is also in a nice neighborhood with great shopping.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. fried rice with crispy duck
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom. fried taro root dumpling and har gau

pkz9iUSe41UUDpsOHxDHJA.text: Had a fabulous time here yesterday. Love the funky lux decor and comfy booths. The szechwan dumplings were perfect - really fresh produce you could tell! I also got the lettuce wraps which were surprisingly filling, and the glass noodles which had a perfect amount of crunch! The staff were incredibly friendly and we felt really looked after, esp by Kathryna, whose warm demeanour made my evening. They're clearly getting things right here and I preferred it to last week's date at Yautcha! Can't wait to return :)

Lp2HHQp2oj89xB8vP8t8lQ.text: Yum!This place is so delicious and well worth a visit. Definitely make a reservation because it gets packed. We ordered several dishes - the Szechuan dumplings, edamame, chicken wings, Singapore fried noodles, green beans with minced pork, and the signature dish of duck and rice - and everything was amazing.The wings in particular stood out for us because they were super crispy and easy to eat. Basically, it was all the 'wing' portion (no 'drumstick'-looking bits) that were split in half so each piece only had one bone inside, which meant you could bite all of the meat off in one go; did that make any sense? The dipping sauce was just fish sauce with chilies and our server recommended we squeeze in the lime. It was phenomenal.The duck was super tender so they definitely know what they're doing and are allowed to have the name that they do.The noodles were just slightly spicy (we were hoping for more of a kick) but executed really well.There were only two of us dining so in the end, we had quite a few leftovers to take home and  our waiter kindly wrapped everything up for us neatly.It is rather pricey, but I think it's nice for a special occasion. Our special occasion was that we were on holiday in London, so there you go.

HuHg4E8qUcJ0XKz0eiMN8A.text: We could not have enjoyed The Duck and Rice more.   The could quite possibly be the best Chinese I've ever had.  We are upstairs which the whole restaurant is fun and modern.  They have big, functional copper Pilsner Urquell containers which are cool as I'm a fan of Czech Pilsners.  The wife and I split 3 apps and 1 main course.  Pork Belly with cabbage, smoked rib Bao bun, lettuce leaf wraps, and Kung Po chicken as the main course.  We definitely ordered too much, but that's ok because we got to eat everything.  All the food rocked.

uawGHZH-pYOpm6OTgh1QuA.text: Duck is really nice in this place! And the staff friendly. Hard to get a table though as its busy (obviously with this delicious duck) so make sure you make a reservation some days in advance.

photos.caption: Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Duck and Rice - London, United Kingdom
